document.docAuthor: Silva, Leonardo De Oliveira Cardoso Da & Lopes, Sonia Maria
document.masterDocTitle: Three new species of the genus Poeciloderrhis Stål, 1874 from Brazil (Blattodea Blaberidae, Epilamprinae) and neotype designation for Poeciloderrhis imperialis Rocha e Silva & Jurberg, 1978

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Three new species of the genus Poeciloderrhis Stål, 1874 from Brazil (Blattodea Blaberidae, Epilamprinae) and neotype designation for Poeciloderrhis imperialis Rocha e Silva & Jurberg, 1978

mods:name.mods:namePart: Silva, Leonardo De Oliveira Cardoso Da
mods:name.mods:affiliation: Department of Entomology, Museu Nacional, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Quinta da Boa Vista s / nº, São Cristóvão, RJ, Brazil.
Department of Entomology, Museu Nacional, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Quinta da Boa Vista s / nº, São Cristóvão, RJ, Brazil.

heading.emphasis:
Key to species of
Poeciloderrhis Stål, 1874

paragraph.keyLead:
1. Total length less than or equal to 18 mm ............................................
P. minoris Silva & Lopes, 2015

3. Basal portion of discoidal and anal fields of tegmen covered more than 40% with dark-brown pigmentation ( Fig. 32 )........................................................................
P. imperialis Rocha e Silva & Jurberg, 1978

4. Abdomen with base of tergite II with dark brown, hook-shaped projection (see Fig. 52 in Roth, 1970 )............................................................................................ …
P. verticalis (Burmeister, 1838)

- Abdomen with base of tergite II bearing projection of mount, cavity or a pendulum shape (see Figs. 4 , 20 , 30 , 40 in Silva & Lopes 2015 , Figs 23 , 43, 53 in Silva & Lopes 2018 )…........................................................ 5

5. Head with region underneath ocelli black (see
Fig. 5
in Silva & Lopes 2018 ); second abdominal tergite with median part bearing two elevations (see
Fig. 7
in Silva & Lopes 2018 )…...................................................... 6

- Head with region underneath ocelli light brown to brown (see
Fig. 31
in Silva & Lopes 2018 ), second abdominal tergite bearing only one elevation (see Fig. 43 in Roth, 1970 ).............................................................… 7

6. Head with entire region of clypeus brown (see
Fig. 5
in Silva & Lopes 2018 ); length of tegmina more than 35 mm …................................................................................
P. aureolatus Silva & Lopes, 2018
- Head with apical region of clypeus light brown ( Fig. 23 ); length of tegmina less than 28 mm ......................... 19

7. Male genitalia with rounded preapical extension of median sclerite (see
Fig. 23
in Roth 1970 )......................................................................................................
P. atriventris (Saussure, 1895)

- Male genitalia without preapical extension of median sclerite (see
Fig. 13
in Lopes & Oliveira 2006 )......................................................................................... ..
P. paulistensis Lopes & Oliveira, 2006

8. Head vertex with four brown marks (see
Fig. 15
in Silva & Lopes 2018 ) ........................................... 9

- Head vertex with fewer than four brown marks (see
Fig. 31
in Silva & Lopes 2018 )................................. 12

9. Head sub-ocular region without pigmentation; tegmina not reaching apical third of abdomen (see Fig. 41 in Roth 1970 )..................................................................................
P. catharina (Shelford, 1910)

10. Abdomen with tergite III bearing basal hump (see Fig. 40 in Silva & Lopes 2015 )…......
P. tijucana Silva and Lopes, 2015

11. Male genitalia with shaft of median sclerite straight (see Fig. 57 in Silva & Lopes 2018 )…....................................................................................................
P. vanzolinii Silva and Lopes, 2018

- Male genitalia with shaft of median sclerite sinuous (see
Fig. 24
in Silva & Lopes 2015 )….....................................................................................................
P. caracensis Silva & Lopes, 2015

12. In ventral view, right style slightly shorter than left style (see Fig. 35 from Silva & Lopes 2018 )…...........................................................................................
P . diamantinense Silva & Lopes, 2018

13. Tegmen not reaching apex of abdomen….....................................
P. boraceiana Lopes & Oliveira, 2006

14. Cerci not reaching apex of supra-anal plate (see Fig. 41 in Roth 1970 )….........
P. santosi (Rocha e Silva & Lopes, 1976)

15. Base of tergite II bearing a cavity followed by a pendulum-shaped structure (see
Fig. 4
in Silva & Lopes 2015 )…..........................................................................
P. ferruginea (Brunner von Wattenwyl, 1865)

17. Marginal field of tegmina with intense pigmentation ( Fig. 2 )…...................................
P.angelus
sp. nov.

- Marginal field of tegmina without intense pigmentation (see Fig. 60 in Silva & Lopes 2018 )…...............................................................................................
P. penduloides Silva and Lopes, 2018

18. General coloration dark-brown ( Fig. 12 )................................................
P. mangaratibensis
sp. nov.

- General coloration light-brown (see Fig. 40 in Silva & Lopes 2018 )…................
P. itatiaiensis Silva & Lopes, 2018

19. Median sclerite with preapical lateral projection (see
Fig. 28
in Silva & Lopes 2018 )…...............................................................................................
P. mediansclerostylatus Silva & Lopes, 2018

- Median sclerite without preapical lateral projection ( Fig.30 )…...............................
P. marombensis
sp. nov.
